snp3.5:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
snp3.5:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

snp3.5:1.3.pli: Atha kho māgho māṇavo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
snp3.5:1.3.eng: Then the student Māgha approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
snp3.5:1.3.comm: Māgha (“bounteous one”) is from the Vedic word magha, “gift, bounty”. It is a name of Sakka (SN 2.3), as is the synonymous Maghavā (SN 11.12:1.3, SN 11.13:6.1). The good king of MN 83 is named Maghadeva, “god of bounty”.

snp3.5:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
snp3.5:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

snp3.5:1.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho māgho māṇavo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

snp3.5:2.1.pli: “Ahañhi, bho gotama, dāyako dānapati vadaññū yācayogo;
snp3.5:2.1.eng: “I’m a giver, worthy Gotama, a donor; I am bountiful and committed to charity.

snp3.5:2.2.eng: I seek wealth in a principled manner,

snp3.5:2.3.pli: dhammena bhoge pariyesitvā dhammaladdhehi bhogehi dhammādhigatehi ekassapi dadāmi dvinnampi tiṇṇampi catunnampi pañcannampi channampi sattannampi aṭṭhannampi navannampi dasannampi dadāmi, vīsāyapi tiṃsāyapi cattālīsāyapi paññāsāyapi dadāmi, satassapi dadāmi, bhiyyopi dadāmi.
snp3.5:2.3.eng: and with that legitimate wealth I give to one person, to two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred people or even more.

snp3.5:2.4.pli: Kaccāhaṃ, bho gotama, evaṃ dadanto evaṃ yajanto bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavāmī”ti?
snp3.5:2.4.eng: Giving and sacrificing like this, worthy Gotama, do I accrue much merit?”

snp3.5:3.1.pli: “Taggha tvaṃ, māṇava, evaṃ dadanto evaṃ yajanto bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavasi.

snp3.5:3.2.pli: Yo kho, māṇava, dāyako dānapati vadaññū yācayogo;
snp3.5:3.2.eng: A giver or donor who is bountiful and committed to charity,

snp3.5:3.3.eng: who seeks wealth in a principled manner,

snp3.5:3.4.pli: dhammena bhoge pariyesitvā dhammaladdhehi bhogehi dhammādhigatehi ekassapi dadāti …pe… satassapi dadāti, bhiyyopi dadāti, bahuṃ so puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
snp3.5:3.4.eng: and with that legitimate wealth gives to one person, or up to a hundred people or even more, accrues much merit.”

snp3.5:3.5.pli: Atha kho māgho māṇavo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi—
snp3.5:3.5.eng: Then Māgha addressed the Buddha in verse:

snp3.5:4.4.eng: Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charity

snp3.5:4.5.eng: makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit.

snp3.5:4.6.eng: Giving food and drink to others here,

snp3.5:5.1.eng: “Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charity,”

snp3.5:5.3.eng: “makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit,

snp3.5:5.4.eng: giving food and drink to others here:

snp3.5:5.5.eng: such a one would succeed due to those <j>who are worthy of donations.”
snp3.5:5.5.comm: Bodhi translates ārādhaye as simple present tense here (“succeeds”) and in the identical line below as imperative (“should accomplish”). Norman has the optative mood in both cases, which is surely correct.

snp3.5:6.1.eng: “Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charity,”

snp3.5:6.3.eng: “makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit,

snp3.5:6.4.eng: giving food and drink to others here:

snp3.5:6.5.eng: explain to me who is worthy of donations.”

snp3.5:7.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:7.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:8.1.eng: Those who have cut off all fetters and bonds,

snp3.5:8.2.eng: tamed, liberated, untroubled, with no need for hope:

snp3.5:8.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:8.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:9.1.eng: Those who are released from all fetters,

snp3.5:9.2.eng: tamed, liberated, untroubled, with no need for hope:

snp3.5:9.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:9.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:10.1.eng: Having given up greed, hate, and delusion,

snp3.5:10.2.eng: with defilements ended, <j>the spiritual journey completed:

snp3.5:10.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:10.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:11.1.pli: Yesu na māyā vasati na māno,
snp3.5:11.1.eng: Those in whom dwells no deceit or conceit,

snp3.5:11.2.eng: with defilements ended, <j>the spiritual journey completed:

snp3.5:11.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:11.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:12.1.eng: Those rid of greed, unselfish, with no need for hope,

snp3.5:12.2.eng: with defilements ended, <j>the spiritual journey completed:

snp3.5:12.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:12.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:13.1.eng: Those not fallen prey to cravings,

snp3.5:13.2.eng: who, having crossed the flood, live unselfishly:

snp3.5:13.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:13.4.eng: should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.

snp3.5:14.1.eng: Those with no craving at all in the world

snp3.5:14.2.eng: for any state of existence in this life or the next:

snp3.5:14.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:14.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:15.1.eng: Those who have left sensuality behind, <j>wandering homeless,

snp3.5:15.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:15.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:16.1.eng: Those freed of greed, with senses stilled,

snp3.5:16.2.eng: like the moon released from the eclipse:

snp3.5:16.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:16.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:17.1.eng: Those assuaged ones free of greed and anger,

snp3.5:17.2.eng: for whom there are no destinies, <j>being rid of them in this life:

snp3.5:17.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:17.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:18.1.eng: They’ve given up rebirth and death completely,

snp3.5:18.2.eng: and have gone beyond all indecision:

snp3.5:18.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:18.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:19.1.eng: Those who live as their own island,

snp3.5:19.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:19.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:20.1.pli: Ye hettha jānanti yathā tathā idaṃ,
snp3.5:20.1.eng: Those here who know this to be true:

snp3.5:20.2.eng: ‘This is my last life, there are no future lives’:

snp3.5:20.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:20.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.5:21.1.eng: A knowledge master, loving absorption, mindful,

snp3.5:21.2.eng: who has reached awakening and is a refuge for many:

snp3.5:21.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.5:21.4.eng: should bestow a timely offering as sacrifice.”

snp3.5:22.1.eng: “Clearly my questions were not in vain!”

snp3.5:22.3.eng: “The Buddha has explained to me <j>who is worthy of donations.

snp3.5:22.4.eng: You are the one here who knows this to be true,

snp3.5:22.5.pli: Tathā hi te vidito esa dhammo.
snp3.5:22.5.eng: for truly you understand this matter.

snp3.5:23.1.eng: Suppose a lay donor who is committed to charity

snp3.5:23.2.eng: makes a sacrifice seeking merit, looking for merit,

snp3.5:23.3.eng: giving food and drink to others here:

snp3.5:23.4.eng: explain to me how to accomplish the sacrifice.”

snp3.5:24.1.comm: The “speaker’s mark” is in MS treated as part of the line, which is unusual if not unique. According to Norman’s note here however, we should consider this line a seven-syllable sloka (perhaps restoring the variant ca to make it eight). I have adjusted the Pali punctuation accordingly.

snp3.5:24.3.eng: “be clear and confident in every way.

snp3.5:24.4.eng: Sacrifice is the ground standing upon which

snp3.5:25.1.eng: One free of greed, rid of anger,

snp3.5:25.2.eng: developing a heart of limitless love,

snp3.5:25.3.eng: spreads that limitlessness in every direction,

snp3.5:26.1.comm: Bajjhati (“bound”) seems odd to me in this line. I think it’s more likely these are three semi-synonyms. As it stands, the Buddha does not actually answer the question, since he only discusses the positive side. PTS notes a reading bujjhati in the commentary, which I follow. However the commentary reads bajjhati in the VRI edition, and the comment itself supports this, since it treats it as a bad thing. If it is a mistake, then, it is an old one.

snp3.5:26.2.eng: How can one go to the realm of divinity oneself?

snp3.5:26.3.eng: I do not know, so please tell me when asked,

snp3.5:26.4.eng: for the Buddha is the divinity I see in person today!

snp3.5:26.5.eng: To us you are truly the equal of divinity.

snp3.5:26.6.eng: Brilliant One, how is one reborn in the realm of divinity?”

snp3.5:27.1.eng: “One who accomplishes the sacrifice <j>with three modes,”

snp3.5:27.3.eng: “such a one would succeed <j>due to those who are worthy of donations.

snp3.5:27.4.eng: Sacrificing like this, one rightly committed to charity

snp3.5:27.5.eng: is reborn in the realm of divinity, I say.”

snp3.5:28.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, māgho māṇavo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.5:28.1.eng: When he had spoken, the student Māgha said to the Buddha,

snp3.5:28.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
